div.head: Congregationalism and the Evangelical Magazine
div.p: In a letter of 3 March 1823 to John James Ruskin, Margaret Ruskin mentions receiving this publication (Ruskin Family Letters, ed. Burd, 121). Her remark does not make clear when the Ruskinsʼ subscription began, but it might be significant that, with the 1823 issues, the magazine initiated volume 1 of a new series.

div.head: The Evangelical Magazine and Missionary Chronicle, the London Missionary Society, and Middle‐Class Congregationalism
div.p: The Evangelical Magazine was founded in 1793 as a nondenominational voice of evangelical culture, embracing Anglican Evangelicalism, Old Dissent, and New Dissent (Altholz, Religious Press in Britain, 45). That spirit of pan‐evangelical catholicity of opinion and mission was reaffirmed at the start of the new series of the magazine in 1823, but the position was being tested. A “Retrospect” published in the first issue of the new series admitted to the emergence of rival denominational publications on both the Anglican Evangelical and Congregational sides. In fact, the editorship of the Evangelical Magazine itself became dominated by Congregationalists, just as that sect prevailed within the organization that the magazine most prominently represented, the London Missionary Society (LMS) (“Retrospect of the Former Series of the Evangelical Magazine”, 1; Altholz, Religious Press in Britain, 46; Thorne, Congregational Missions and the Making of an Imperial Culture, 24).

So much of each issue was given over to the section entitled The Missionary Chronicle containing news and formal reports of LMS activity that the Ruskinsʼ (or at least Margaretʼs) regular reading of the Evangelical Magazine implies a strong interest in missionary work. Indeed, the enthusiasm surrounding foreign missions accounts for a significant part of what tied the Ruskins to Congregationalism at this time, as documented by Ruskin's "a theme", which is a transcript or summary of a meeting for soliciting missionary support, as well as by the entire family's eager reading of the journals and poetry of the Reverend Reginald Heber, Bishop of Calcutta. (Another part of their attraction to Congregationalism can be attributed to the preaching and evangelical energy of the Reverend Dr. Edward Andrews.)

The Ruskins were not uncharacteristic in being bound to Congregationalism by the excitement surrounding foreign missions. ??? Thorne argues that this commitment was a key to coalescing a middle-class identity within Congregationalism. In the late eighteenth century, Thorne explains, "missions were a distinctively middle-class alternative to gentry modes of authority, a means of controlling the lower orders at home as well as abroad that was in direct opposition to traditional or gentry forms of rule‚Äù. "This is not to say", she goes on, "that the missionary language of opposition was antiauthoritarian, much less antinational" (Thorne, Congregational Missions and the Making of an Imperial Culture, 39, 43). The latter caveat applies especially to the Ruskins, who were not radical Dissenters, nor were the 1820s the revolutionary 1780s and '90s. It is perhaps telling that, in the second half of the 1820s, the Congregational chapel in Camberwell was led by the Reverend William Orme (1787–1830), who, years earlier, had parted ways with his first mentor, Richard Haldane (0000–00), who was both "one of Scotland's leading advocates of foreign missionary expansion" and a fervent supporter of the French Revolution. For the Ruskins, even Orme's chapel, if not Orme himself, may have borne too much the air of the "Protestant Dissenting Meeting House", as it was then called, as compared with "Dr. Andrews's Chapel" as named in the Evangelical Magazine (Gordon and Pimlott, “Orme, William [1787–1830]”; Thorne, Congregational Missions and the Making of an Imperial Culture, 44 [on Haldane], 58-59 [on the increased working-class presence in Congregationalism in the wake of the Evangelical Revival; and see "the theme": Discussion).

Middle-class Congregationalism was organized around fund-raising for foreign missions, following the catastrophe of the initially fervent but ill-conceived Congregational missions to the South Seas. Funded by a few wealthy patrons, and relying for success on the will of God, the ill-equipped and uninformed missions fell apart; consequently, the LMS reorganized fundraising on a broader basis, soliciting contributions both modest and substantial, metropolitan and provincial (Thorne, Congregational Missions and the Making of an Imperial Culture, 59-62). This operation was reported in detail in the "Missionary Chronicle", which formed a lengthy portion of each issue of the Evangelical Magazine by the time Margaret Ruskin became a subscriber. The published tables of contributions to the LMS, were calculated, as Sujit Sivasundaram argues, to inspire readers with a collective experience of evangelical zeal. The lists were observantly detailed, even listing contributors of used copies of the magazine to be sent to missionaries abroad, who duly reported back with their gratitude for reports from the parent organization, not to mention their relief for fresh reading to palliate the tedium of their missions. Readers, in turn, felt they played a part in a worldwide evangelistic effort, regardless of their level of donation (Sivasundaram, “The Periodical as Barometer”, 43–48).

div.head: The Evangelical Magazine, the London Missionary Society and Print Culture
div.p: Such outreach as the "Missionary Chronicle" was characteristic of the LMSʼs larger effort in print culture, which Anna Johnston describes as the construction of “a reading audience through its canny manipulation of textual and media technologies, a readership that would unite religious Britons in a common cause despite differences of class, region, gender, and age” (“British Missionary Publishing”, 30). The young John Ruskin was captured by the excitement, as evidenced by "a theme", which appears to record a speech or sermon at a meeting of a missionary society. Ruskin was also vulnerable to the appeal of missionary celebrity, as shown by his starstruck enthusiasm for the poetry and journals of Reginald Heber, Bishop of Calcutta.

Besides reporting on the missionary activities of the LMS, the EVANGELICALMAGEvangelical Magazine addressed other interests that probably engaged the Ruskin family. Each issue contained a section of poetry, albeit usually pious in subject matter; and the January issue routinely printed poems for the New Year, which may have influenced Ruskinʼs custom of composing a New Yearʼs ode to be fair‐copied and presented to his father on New Yearʼs. Feature articles mainly concerned religious topics but occasionally encompassed other areas of knowledge, such as natural history. A section of book reviews and brief notices of religious publications, including pious works for children, evidently informed the elder Ruskinsʼ choice of some books for John, since some notices correspond to books that he is known to have owned (see Books Used by Ruskin in His Youth—Physical Descriptions). Among the most prominent features in each issue were lengthy obituaries and biographies of celebrated clergy, embellished by their engraved portraits, which supplied the sole graphic interest in each issue apart from the engraved banner. These biographies exposed the reader to peoples, landscapes, and customs of cultures around the world, albeit filtered through the perception of missionaries.
